DataElement.preferredName: Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Cytogenetics Metaphase Nucleus Result Count
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a numeric value counting cell nuclei (organelles) captured in the second phase of mitosis as an outcome from a lab procedure to map chromosomes using fluorescent tags and detect abnormalities.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Cytogenetics Metaphase Nucleus Result
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to cell nuclei (organelles) seen in the second phase of mitosis as the outcome from a lab procedure to map chromosomes using fluorescent tags and detect abnormalities.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A type of IN SITU HYBRIDIZATION in which target sequences are stained with fluorescent dye so their location and size can be determined using fluorescence microscopy. This staining is sufficiently distinct that the hybridization signal can be seen both in metaphase spreads and in interphase nuclei.:Cytogenetics is the study of chromosomes and the related disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.
The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

Property.preferredDefinition: Arrangement of chromosomes in the equatorial plane of the central spindle to form the monaster.  Chromosomes separate into exactly similar halves. (NCI):Within a eukaryotic cell, a membrane-limited body which contains chromosomes and one or more nucleoli (CELL NUCLEOLUS). The nuclear membrane consists of a double unit-type membrane which is perforated by a number of pores; the outermost membrane is continuous with the ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM. A cell may contain more than one nucleus. (From Singleton & Sainsbury, Dictionary of Microbiology and Molecular Biology, 2d ed):Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: The second phase of mitosis, in which the chromosomes line up across the equatorial plane of the spindle prior to separation.
A body within the cell, surrounded by a membrane, within which lie the chromosomes, one or more nucleoli, combined with proteins, and exhibits mitosis.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: new version created to complete associations with EVS terms

ValueDomain.preferredName: Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Cytogenetics Nucleus Result Count
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a numeric value counting the organelles within cells that contain genetic material as an outcome from a laboratory procedure which maps chromosomes using fluorescent tags to detect abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: Determining the number or amount of something.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: new version to correct incorrect use of Rep term

AlternateNames.name: Fluorescence In Situ Hybrid Cytogenetics Metaphase Nucleus Result Count

ReferenceDocuments.description: updated to make association to correct EVS terms
